description:
Trichoplusia ni, commonly known as the cabbage looper, is a species of moth belonging to the family Noctuidae. It is a widely distributed pest found in various parts of the world, including North America, Europe, and Asia.

The adult Trichoplusia ni moth has a wingspan of approximately 30-40 mm. The forewings are grayish-brown in color, with a distinct silver or white "Y-shaped" mark near the center. The hindwings are pale grayish-brown.

The larvae, or caterpillars, of Trichoplusia ni are called "cabbage loopers" due to their characteristic looping movement as they crawl. The larvae are green in color with a white stripe along each side of their body. They can cause significant damage to a variety of crops, including cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower, and other brassicas, by feeding on the leaves and foliage.

Trichoplusia ni undergoes complete metamorphosis, with four distinct life stages: egg, larva, pupa, and adult moth. The species is known for its ability to migrate long distances, contributing to its widespread distribution and economic importance as an agricultural pest.
